title: How is life being rich in China? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you want to know about those super rich, it's really no difference in most country - plus most super rich people have multiple homes in all world's top cities (New York, London, Shanghai, Singapore... what's over), for the super rich, nationality never matters - they are usually citizen of multiple countries depending on various tax policy. If you are asking about the generally believed richer group, I do believe in every country it's different, and in China, if you either: - Have 3+ homes in tie-1 cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen)- or run a small business that brings in a turnover of over 1 million RMB  (~200K USD) per year- or earns a salary of over 1 million RMB per year.You are considered rich. And your life: Live in top 10% neighborhood in the city.Kids go to top 10% middle school (college education cannot be bought with money so far)Travel 3+ times per year, and knows some weird geography term not many knows.Tend to spoil your kids with money, unlike western rich parents, Chinese parents enjoys making their kids feel superior with their money.And still work hard like a dog.Your neighbourhood:  Inside your home:   Your kid study here:  You spend lots of time buying here:  You obtained the license to do this:  You made people here complaining home price:  Everything else would be not much different, you just travel more, and has the luxury of going to expensive destinations like the South pole,

Once we had a talk about this topic with friends, most of who MBA aluminums. One lady said she used to think if she had 10M RMB cash + 2 set of apartments in the core area of Shanghai, she would be satisfied and felt safe enough to no more working like a dog. And 2 years later she actually made it, after she and her husband, both previous McKinsey EMs, managed to transfer to the customer side. At that time base on my estimation they had a annual pre tax income at least 3M-4M RMB And as Shanghai natives they had 3+ apartments which at least worth more than 20M RMB. I pointed out my estimation to her and asked her why she was still work so hard?  And she just smiled atme and said:" but that is just the money we need 2 years ago with one kid, since we are going to have 2 kids, they are not enough any more" The point is they still led a life as same as before and as same as most of the other shanghainess, the only differences is just their apartment a little bigger and better located and more oversea vacations. Not for one day they could convice themselves that they are safe enough to stop working so hard.. That's how an upper-middle class in a fast-growing economics feel and think...

we chinese always consider the one whose assets values over 1m RMB as the rich, a reserch shows  that  the number of chinese millionare is over 1 million as to 2015,it's a huge group,and this group includes company owners,managers,,,,,,the elite rank as other coutries,and the have the same or similar lifestyle as other society.i will barely describe one special kind of millionare which we called Tuhao(means have much money but less education), most Tuhao get rich for their old house  in the  city was  taken by real estate developers to build new apartement,when they get such amount of money in a flash,the only  plan  they have is  to make themselves a point to show they are rich,and they dont have a good behavior or taste. be rich can be more respective by others ,a rich young man wont need to work hard to buy a house in big city like shanghai ( pretty stressful),without a house ,marriage is more hard, it is time to bed ,add more later

I believe most wealthy people have mixed feelings. On the one hand it gives you a lot of opportunities for both yourself and your family. You can afford to send your kid to a good school and possibly a top university abroad. You can afford traveling and buying whatever you need.  On the other hand, wealth in China usually also brings along anxiety. This is partly measured in the  China Private Wealth Report which basically shows that 56% of Chinese people with personal assets exceeding 10 million RMB are considering emigrating. For most people it's because they perceive other countries to be safer in terms of environment and better in terms of education, but many wealthy people are also establishing homes overseas as a "getaway plan" in case the source of their wealth was exposed.  Another survey found that 78% of Chinese entrepreneurs experience high or moderate anxiety while less than 2% experience no anxiety. This anxiety usually stems from a lack of trust in the law and a related feeling that accumulated wealth is never safe.

Remarkably similar to what it is like to be rich anywhere else. The wealthy in China have a disproportionately greater say in internal affairs, have more spending power, better political connections, more access to luxury goods a stronger media presence, can provide better opportunities like education and healthcare for their children and are more likely to hold political office (especially high level national offices). They're also more likely to face prison time or labor camp time than get executed if they step out of line. Believe it or not being part of the wealthy elite of any society is pretty much awesome, it doesn't really matter which society that is. Wealthy elite of Iran? Awesome. Wealthy elite of China? Awesome. The consistent factor here is wealthy elite, not the individual society itself. I think that's fairly well contained in the premise of 'wealthy elite'.

While I was pursuing my PhD in chemical engineering, I had the privilege to live in China on a few occasions. During this time I had free housing in the nicest part of town and an American PhD fellowship. Now, this isn't rich by American standards but I was definitely rich by the vast majority of Chinese standards. My local Chinese friends were amazed that I had my own apartment in my 20s, as they all lived at home. I could afford to eat amazing food everyday and do almost any activity I wanted. I have since returned to China on many occasions because they are very hospitable, 和我也很喜欢中国菜！哈哈。

The extremely rich (especially without political background) would rather stay away from the public sight, since the ones appear in Forbes China probably get closer to prisons. The former most wealthy man in China, Mr Huang is still in the prison now and just received reduction in penalty last month. The fairly rich people closed to our working class are carefree in consumption: buy buy  buy and never mind price.
